title: I don't like maths because it's not something I can play with mentally. There's no gymnastics, no mystery, no drama- there's just people pretending that these irrelevant numbers will solve everyday problems. Why do people use maths? - Quora

response.answer_text: Imagine learning to drive a car in middle school. The drivers-education teacher set up traffic cones in a parking lot to practice driving in a straight line, making turns, signaling before making turns, perpendicular parking, parallel parking, etc. The students also have written tests in traffic laws. However, they are never allowed to drive in traffic, because they are too young for drivers' licenses. The 8th-graders would have a little excitement in operating a powerful machine, but most of the class would be boring. That is what math classes are like. A better written analogy written by Paul Lockhart is A Mathematician’s Lament (https://www.maa.org/external_archive/devlin/LockhartsLament.pdf). Of course, children know that driving a car opens up interesting places to visit. They travel by a car driven by their parents. My two daughters learned the elegance of mathematics simply from hanging around me. My younger daughter told me, "You treat mathematics as art." They tutored their classmates in high school and college, because they had no fear of mathematics. Sadly, most families do not learn to treat mathematics playfully or artistically, because the boring math classes have been around for generations. I was an exception because my father was an engineer who gave us children science kits, such as Lectron electronics sets (Raytheon Lectron - Wikipedia) and Estes model rockets (Estes Industries - Wikipedia). I learned the math along with the science. Some mathematics is so amusing it is called recreational mathematics (Recreational mathematics - Wikipedia). Another childhood influence on me was Martin Gardner's collections of Mathematics Games articles (a few at Mathematical Association of America and more diverse material at Martin Gardner Home Site). Other mathematicians such as Ian Stewart continued Martin Gardner's tradition. Solve some puzzles at Interactive Mathematics Miscellany, learn fold a hexaflexagon from Vi Hart https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Svq2Kscmmwc, watch animated proofs at 3Blue1Brown 3Blue1Brown, and enjoy yourself.

Of course it is not irrelevant when you are in the DIY store trying to buy floor tiles (how many packs do you need, when each pack has 6 tiles that are 18″ x 8″?), or when you are calculating the number of transistors you can fit in a certain area of silicon (admittedly not something common people need to concern with, but your mobile phone or computer would not work if they didn’t get that about right!), what speed the rocket should have to reach the moon, what time you will arrive at grandma’s if you leave now, or many, many other more or less daily maths problems. I agree, there’s no mystery, nearly all mathematical problems have been solved, you just need to apply the formula that someone else came up with. I’m not sure I can convince you, but there are certainly useful and common applications of mathematics. Of course, with the existence of the internet, you can always ask “How long does it take to do 80 miles at 70 mph?” on quora. Certainly 40 other people have solved their homework that way.

In reality, you can play with math mentally. It’s pretty much the basis of mental math. Math is filled with all sorts of gymnastics, mystery and drama. Mathematics is not irrelevant numbers, and no one is pretending these “irrelevant numbers” will solve everyday problems. A lot of everyday problems are solved by very relevant maths. Think about it, you can pick anything in the world, and if you look close enough, there is an insane amount of math that went into its creation. Math is also the foundation of the sciences and technology. Without math at some level, Quora would not exist for you to use today. Sorry about my rant, but try to understand why math exists, and how much it helps your life before dismissing it as irrelevant, useless or difficult.

This is your question in a world where numbers allow routing of IP packets: I don't like maths because it's not something I can play with mentally. There's no gymnastics, no mystery, no drama- there's just people pretending that these irrelevant numbers will solve everyday problems. Why do people use maths? This is your question in a world where they don’t: . Do you not see the irony of using a global computer network to complain that numbers have no purpose?

What maths have you been doing? What’s the smallest number that is the sum of two cubes in two different ways? Finding it might be tedious, but look for the story behind it. One mathematician spent a cab ride think it was uninteresting at his destination another mathematician told them a way that it wasn’t. Also, in real life, I solved a geocaching problem for my mum by recognising said number. 10 digits are far more fascinating that 26 letters and the English language. (yes, I know their names, but if you don’t know they are mathematicians the story is more bizarre, plus I don’t want to make finding the number trivial).

People get obsessed with getting questions right which is nonsense and will let your knowledge grind to a halt at some point it is vital that you understand all the boring language once you do applying it is a breeze.. I am learning sudoku at the moment and have spent an hour today watching a couple of annoying videos with a lot of repetition in them however this repetition will reinforce my learning……..

I use arithmetic a lot to see how much of a given resource I need in Minecraft. I’ve also used it to figure out what I could do with 50 amps living in an RV and approximately how amps many circuits in my house carry. I multiply fractions a look when cooking. My husband uses maps to model epidemics and statistically analyze experimental data. Despite being dry, math has application all over STEM and blue collar work.

I find maths very handy to know if I am being paid fairly or if someone is trying to cheat me. Then to work out if I have saved enough for a mortgage, and what the mortgage is going to cost me (a mortgage loan say for 200k always costs a lot more than 200k by the time it is paid off). And there have been occasions when mathematical formulae have helped me in other ways,

I play with numbers mentally all the time and they are not irrelevant! You buy an item that costs $15 dollars with the tax. You hand the store person a $20 dollar bill and get only $3 change! Do you need a pencil and paper to know you have just been screwed out of $2?
Math is a game to train you to be logical. If there was no math, you wouldn’t have an iphone/computer/electronical device to post this question in the first place.
